title: Scenario 1: The Onboarding Bottleneck
scenario: A new Member Onboarding workflow is due tomorrow. You’ve finished your scripts, but a teammate is struggling with a technical hurdle in the automation. This teammate is your peer.

options.label: A
options.text: Send your completed work to the manager immediately to show you’ve met your deadline.

options.label: B
options.text: Offer to hop on a call with the teammate to share your process and help them troubleshoot.

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for the teammate to ask for help; you don’t want to overstep or make them feel incompetent.

options.label: D
options.text: Check your work one more time to ensure your "A+" is secured, then head home.

title: Scenario 2: The Funnel Shortcut
scenario: You’ve discovered a shortcut in the Marketing Funnel CRM that saves you two hours of manual lead tracking every week.

options.label: A
options.text: Keep it to yourself so you can use that extra time for personal projects and stand out.

options.label: B
options.text: Mention it to your manager during your next 1-on-1 to show your individual innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Document the process and share it with the team so everyone can save time.

options.label: D
options.text: Use the shortcut but only share it if you see someone else specifically struggling.

title: Scenario 3: The Unearned Praise
scenario: During a meeting, your manager praises you for a brilliant idea that was actually sparked by a casual comment a teammate made during lunch.

options.label: A
options.text: Accept the praise; it was your execution that made the idea work anyway.

options.label: B
options.text: Thank the manager, then privately tell the teammate later that you appreciated their input.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediately speak up: "I can't take full credit; [Name] brought up the core concept."

options.label: D
options.text: Say "The team worked hard on this," without naming the specific person.

title: Scenario 4: The Ecological Design Query
scenario: A potential member sends an urgent technical request about Ecological Design specifics. It falls into a "gray area"—it’s not strictly BI's job, but the person who handles it is at a farm site without signal.

options.label: A
options.text: Explain to the client that the responsible party is out and give them a return date.

options.label: B
options.text: Try to resolve the issue yourself to protect the team’s reputation and help the client.

options.label: C
options.text: Forward the email to your manager so they can decide who should handle it.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the email; responding might set a precedent that you are now responsible for this.

title: Scenario 5: The Campaign Delay
scenario: The Community Engagement campaign launched late. The manager asks what went wrong. You know a teammate forgot an approval, but you also could have checked in on them.

options.label: A
options.text: Stay silent and let the teammate explain themselves; it’s their responsibility.

options.label: B
options.text: Say, "It was a breakdown in communication. I should have followed up to confirm."

options.label: C
options.text: Message the manager after the meeting to clarify exactly whose fault it was.

options.label: D
options.text: Make up a technical excuse (like a server error) to keep everyone out of trouble.

title: Scenario 6: The Documentation Request
scenario: You lead a complex BI process only you know. Your manager asks for a "How-To" manual so others can step in if you are ever unavailable.

options.label: A
options.text: Create a brief outline but leave out the nuances; some things are better learned by doing.

options.label: B
options.text: Create a comprehensive guide so simple that a junior member could handle it.

options.label: C
options.text: Suggest it’s more efficient for you to just do it, as teaching others takes too long.

options.label: D
options.text: Use the request as leverage to ask for a promotion or raise before sharing the info.

title: Scenario 7: The CEO's Weekend Request
scenario: It is Saturday. An urgent issue arises with the Farm Productivity dashboard. The CEO needs a quick 10-minute fix for a Monday presentation.

options.label: A
options.text: Ignore the message until Monday; weekends are a strictly "no-work" zone.

options.label: B
options.text: Provide the info quickly, then suggest a meeting Monday to ensure others have this info.

options.label: C
options.text: Handle the issue, but remind the manager Monday how "lost" the team would be without you.

options.label: D
options.text: Block work contacts during off-hours to ensure your time is never interrupted.

title: Scenario 8: The Broken Build
scenario: You accidentally pushed code that broke the Sales Enablement toolkit. No one has noticed yet, and you could probably fix it quietly in an hour.

options.label: A
options.text: Fix it quietly and hope no one checks the logs.

options.label: B
options.text: Alert the team channel immediately, apologize, and start fixing.

options.label: C
options.text: Wait until someone reports the error, then act surprised.

options.label: D
options.text: Claim the build server has been acting up lately.

title: Scenario 9: The Loudest Voice
scenario: In a planning meeting, the loudest person is pushing a plan you know is flawed. The quietest person has a better idea but isn't speaking up.

options.label: A
options.text: Let the loud person win; it's not worth the conflict.

options.label: B
options.text: Publicly ask the quiet person for their thoughts to give them the floor.

options.label: C
options.text: Message the quiet person later and tell them they should have spoken up.

options.label: D
options.text: Interrupt the loud person aggressively to shut them down.

title: Scenario 10: The AI Support Suggestion
scenario: A junior developer suggests a new AI Integration for Member Support that seems unnecessary to you. You are the senior lead.

options.label: A
options.text: Dismiss it immediately; you know the codebase better.

options.label: B
options.text: Ask them to walk you through their reasoning and prototype it.

options.label: C
options.text: Let them do it, expecting them to fail so they learn a lesson.

options.label: D
options.text: Take the core idea, polish it, and present it as your own optimization.

title: Scenario 11: The Rumor Mill
scenario: You hear a rumor that layoffs are coming. A stressed teammate asks if you know anything.

options.label: A
options.text: Share the rumor to help them prepare, even if it's unverified.

options.label: B
options.text: Say "I haven't heard anything official," and encourage them not to panic.

options.label: C
options.text: Tell them everything is definitely fine to protect their feelings.

options.label: D
options.text: Add your own speculation about which department is at risk.

title: Scenario 12: The CEO's Vague Task
scenario: The CEO assigns you a task regarding 'Sales Enablement Metrics' with very vague instructions. They are currently busy in meetings.

options.label: A
options.text: Wait until they are free to ask for clarification, even if it delays work.

options.label: B
options.text: Draft a proposal of what you think needs doing and send it for async approval.

options.label: C
options.text: Do what you want; if it's wrong, it's their fault for not being clear.

options.label: D
options.text: Complaining to peers that leadership is disorganized.

title: Scenario 13: The Chronic Lateness
scenario: A peer is consistently late to stand-up, which is starting to annoy the team.

options.label: A
options.text: Bring it up in the retrospective publicly to shame them into changing.

options.label: B
options.text: Check in privately to see if everything is okay with their schedule.

options.label: C
options.text: Start showing up late too; fair is fair.

options.label: D
options.text: Report them to the manager immediately.

title: Scenario 14: The Credit Steal (Reverse)
scenario: A colleague takes credit for a small fix you made. It's minor, but annoying.

options.label: A
options.text: Call them out in front of everyone.

options.label: B
options.text: Mention privately: "Hey, glad that fix worked, but please credit me next time."

options.label: C
options.text: Let it slide; you don't want to seem petty.

options.label: D
options.text: Stop helping them in the future.

title: Scenario 15: The Ecological Data Map
scenario: The Ecological Design team is swamped and asks for help with manual plot data mapping. You have free time but it's boring work.

options.label: A
options.text: Decline; you are a developer, not a field analyst.

options.label: B
options.text: Jump in to help clear the backlog; it helps the company's ecological goals.

options.label: C
options.text: Agree only if you can get a favor in return later.

options.label: D
options.text: Do it, but make sure everyone knows you are doing them a huge favor.

title: Scenario 16: The Quick Fix
scenario: You find a bug that will take 3 days to fix properly or 1 hour to patch with a hack.

options.label: A
options.text: Patch it. Speed is what matters most.

options.label: B
options.text: Explain the trade-off to stakeholders and advocate for the proper fix.

options.label: C
options.text: Hide the bug so you don't have to deal with it right now.

options.label: D
options.text: Assign the ticket to someone else.

title: Scenario 17: The Feedback Sandwich
scenario: You need to give critical feedback to a sensitive teammate.

options.label: A
options.text: Be brutally honest; feelings shouldn't matter in business.

options.label: B
options.text: Be direct but kind, focusing on the work behavior, not the person.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid giving the feedback to keep the peace.

options.label: D
options.text: Give so much praise they don't even realize you criticized them.

title: Scenario 18: The Vacation Handover
scenario: You are going on vacation for a week. The Member Onboarding rollout is active.

options.label: A
options.text: Tell them to call you if anything burns down.

options.label: B
options.text: Prepare detailed docs and brief a designated backup person.

options.label: C
options.text: Just set an out-of-office reply; they'll figure it out.

options.label: D
options.text: Secretly check email every day because you don't trust them.

title: Scenario 19: The Team Win
scenario: The new Farm Management tool launched successfully. The CEO asks you how it went.

options.label: A
options.text: Tell them how hard *you* worked to get it over the line.

options.label: B
options.text: Highlight the specific contributions of your teammates.

options.label: C
options.text: Mention the problems you had to overcome (complaining).

options.label: D
options.text: Ask if this means you get a bonus.

title: Scenario 20: The Legacy Reconciliation
scenario: A new hire asks why the Member Finance reconciliation is so bad. You know it was a legacy manual process from years ago.

options.label: A
options.text: Defend the process blindly to show loyalty.

options.label: B
options.text: Explain the historical context honestly but admit it needs improvement.

options.label: C
options.text: Bash the process and the original author to bond with the new hire.

options.label: D
options.text: Tell them not to ask questions like that.
